title: [eslint-config] [breaking] Enable react/no-is-mounted rule
body:
isMounted is an anti-pattern [0](https://facebook.github.io/react/blog/2015/12/16/ismounted-antipattern.html), is not available when using ES6
classes, and is on its way to being officially deprecated.
eslint-plugin-react recently added the react/no-is-mounted rule in
3.12.0 that prevents its use.

Finishes #633

title: Sort react/prefer-es6-class alphabetically
body:
All of the other rules in this file are in alphabetical order, but this
one was added by c98990c0f out of order at the end. Keeping these in
alphabetical order will help developers find the rules that they are
looking for.

title: Enable react/no-is-mounted?
body: Hi folks, since [`isMounted` is an anti-pattern](https://facebook.github.io/react/blog/2015/12/16/ismounted-antipattern.html), is not available when using ES6 classes, and is on its way to being officially deprecated, what do you think about enabling the [react/no-is-mounted](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/blob/master/docs/rules/no-is-mounted.md) rule that was recently released with [3.12.0](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#3120---2015-12-20)? If you are up for it, I'd be happy to submit a PR. (Do you think it should be a warning or an error?)

title: [eslint config] [breaking] enable `quote-props` rule.
body: This is the rule we follow at Airbnb, but the styleguide and linter plugin haven't been enforcing it.

title: Method chaining with prototype
body: Example provided in 9.3  looks like we can not use method chaining with prototype. It's actually possible, so we should put the two different ways.(oh, and I added a function constructor).

title: Alignment of closing bracket of opening tag for components with multi-line properties and children
body:
The style guide has an example of de-indenting the closing bracket of the opening tag for components with multi-line properties and children:

``` jsx
// children get indented normally
<Foo
  superLongParam="bar"
  anotherSuperLongParam="baz"
>
  <Spazz />
</Foo>
```

However, it does not list any reasoning for this, so I wonder if it is arbitrary. I'd like to propose adjusting the alignment of the closing bracket of the opening tag for these components so that they line up with the props instead of the opening bracket. Example:

``` jsx
// children get indented normally
<Foo
  superLongParam="bar"
  anotherSuperLongParam="baz"
  >
  <Spazz />
</Foo>
```

I think this is better for 2 reasons:
1. This is really minor, but since children are props, it makes sense for them to be visually grouped with the rest of the props.
2. More importantly, this style makes it easier to see how components are nested ([as I mentioned in my proposal for this rule](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/64#issuecomment-157767905)). e.g.:

``` jsx
<MyComponent
  myProp="..."
  >
  <MyComponent
    myProp="..."
    >
    <MyComponent
      myProp="..."
      >
      Children
    </MyComponent>
  </MyComponent>
</MyComponent>
```

This can be enforced with the following configuration:

``` js
"jsx-closing-bracket-location": [2, {
  "nonEmpty": "props-aligned", // Align the bracket with the last prop
  "selfClosing": "tag-aligned" // Align the bracket with the opening tag
}]
```

What do you think?

title: Consistent quote style for both JS and JSX?
body:
The [style guide says to prefer single quotes for JS](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#strings). However, [for JSX, it prefers double quotes](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/master/react#quotes) because:

> double quotes make conjunctions like `"don't"` easier to type

Although in practice it probably occurs less frequently, you could make the same argument for using single quotes to make quoted bits like `'Say "hello"'` easier to type.

Still, all of this seems to me to matter less than the consistency that would be gained by choosing either single quotes or double quotes for both JS and JSX. What do you think?

title: Broken Hyperlinks on webpage.
body:
Hi,
Hyperlinks for ES5 and React listed under Other Style Guides are broken on http://airbnb.io/javascript/

title: update best-practices config to prevent parameter object manipulation
body:
added good/bad examples of parameter mutation to the readme

addresses #626

title: no-param-reassign with props
body:
Hey AirBnB,
What are your thoughts about preventing object manipulation on params as well:
http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-param-reassign.html. I know I'm surprised when I pass an object to a function and the function manipulates the object.

The [current value](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/best-practices.js#L77) is set to `2`. What do you think about changing it to `[2, { "props": true }]`?

Thanks!

title: Why disable `console.log`? Seems like a pretty obtuse decision for development.
body: I'm a fan of most of what I see, but I don't particularly understand the decision to disallow `console.log`. I can understand the "it has no place in production" argument, but I also wouldn't want my linter constantly complaining in a development environment.

title: Export default with class name
body:
In the style guide, it says not to use displayName, which I am fine with, but it seems like it discourages the use of `export default` when you can still name a class with
`export default class SomeComponent extends Component {}`.

I think this syntax is better than 

``` javascript
class Something {}
export default Something
```

title: 21.3 Numbers
Remove deprecated react/jsx-quotes
body:
This rule is deprecated, but was reintroduced in #618. Running eslint with this config now prints:

```
The react/jsx-quotes rule is deprecated. Please use the jsx-quotes rule instead.
```

The correct rule is already enforced [here](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/style.js#L29).

title: object-shorthand rule should be enabled
body:
It seems that the object-shorthand rule is incorrectly disabled.

Per the guidelines, object-shorthand is recommended, specifically under [object method shorthand](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#3.5) and [property value shorthand](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#3.6).

Also, the comment in [`eslint-config-airbnb/rules/es6.js`](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/28a83da1d11a200014c7d33abf95b5b1bbf7b604/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/es6.js#L42-L43) indicates that it's a requirement, however the rule is set to 0 (disabled):

``` js
    // require method and property shorthand syntax for object literals
    'object-shorthand': 0,
```

This should be changed to:

``` js
    // require method and property shorthand syntax for object literals
    'object-shorthand': 2,
```

Thanks!

title: Update README.md
body: Add OutBoxSoft to the list of organizations

title: Minor cleanup for the React styleguide
body:
This fixes some minor things that I thought were missing from the styleguide.

If people are unhappy about enforcing names for event handlers or additional render methods, I'm happy to discuss/remove.

---
- Obey our own styleguide for modules.
- Added missing rule for `true` props.
- New rule on event handler binding.

title: [react] Including missing defaults to the react eslint
body: We were missing including the defaults in a couple react rules for the eslint configuration. This adds them back.

title: Require space before/after arrow function's arrow (arrow-spacing)
body:
Enable [arrow-spacing](http://eslint.org/docs/rules/arrow-spacing.html) rule, code with space before/after arrow function's arrow is easier to read:

``` js
() => {};
(a) => {};
a => a;
() => {'\n'};
()=> {};     /*error Missing space before =>*/
() =>{};     /*error Missing space after =>*/
(a)=> {};    /*error Missing space before =>*/
(a) =>{};    /*error Missing space after =>*/
a =>a;       /*error Missing space after =>*/
a=> a;       /*error Missing space before =>*/
()=> {'\n'}; /*error Missing space before =>*/
() =>{'\n'}; /*error Missing space after =>*/
```

title: Recommended import grouping and order?
body:
Is there a recommended import grouping and order for es6 modules?

python has some specifications in PEP as well as some logical extensions: https://code.google.com/p/soc/wiki/PythonStyleGuide#Imports_grouping_and_order

given that es6 imports are reversed, ie instead of:

`from <module> import <function>` (python)
its 
`import <function> from <module>`

sorting by module isn't as intuitive
